column26: I grouped these two sentences together as they both refer to sensation, rather than perception or actual movement
column27: I grouped these sentences together based on intensity. Each of them refer to intensity in terms of either sensation or perception.

column24: "This group relates to sensation, which I think is subtly different from perception. For me these all ask me to rate how much it 'feels' as though I'm moving- the intensity of that sensation, rather than the speed itself."
column25: This group all suggest I should rate how fast I'm going, i.e. more objectively guess at the speed of the train rather than what it feels like or how I perceive it.
column26: Group 3 all relate to perception,  how fast I 'think' I'm going. This is confusing though, how can I 'rate' my own perception? It sounds as though I'm being asked to judge the. accuracy of my own thoughts.

column24: "Train only"
column25: Personal
column26: Combination

column24: "These sentences describe a command to subjectively evaluate how fast you are going. All sentences ask you how fast you are going, from your subjective perspective."
column25: These sentences all ask how fast "you" are moving, rather than how fast the "train" is moving. They are all simple questions that ask for on objective evaluation of how fast "you" are moving.
column26: These sentences are similar to those in Group 2, but they ask how fast the train is moving instead of how fast you are moving. They all ask for an objective evaluation of the train's movements, but not "your" movements.
column27: These sentences all ask about the phenomenological aspects of moving - how do you "feel" it, and what it is like to move, rather than asking for objective measures of how fast you or the train got from A to B. This is different from Group 1, which asks how you subjectively measure moving from A to B, whereas this group is asking about what it feels to be moving from A to B.

column27: here you ask about motion (generic) and referred to me, so I understand you ask about my motion
column28: you ask about self-motion here, which is a specific type of perception (optical flow). This may be confusing to many.
column29: this sounds similar to gr. 3 but it refers to my speed. I would understanding better if it was "was" rather than "are". And it would make more sense if referred to the train, rather than me. Because I was not moving.
